fields.description:
Cached Remote Crowd directories synchronise the user active/inactive status between the cache and the remote Crowd server. LDAP connectors used to not to synchronise this status, until CWD-995, and with CWD-3360, it is now an optional feature.

Ideally, this feature (being able to enable or disable status synchronisation) should be available as well for Remote Crowd directories.
fields.summary: Add an option to locally manage the user active/inactive status for Remote Crowd connectors

fields.description: The Crowd webapp and OpenID Server should protect their login page against CSRF attacks. This prevents attacks where a user is logged in under another set of credentials without their permission, or cases where a client is tricked into helping with brute force attacks.
fields.summary: Include CSRF protection for login pages

fields.description:
When installing Crowd, but stopping Crowd after DB config and then re-starting; Crowd fails to start the plugin system on restart.

The only work around is to delete the Crowd home directory and start again.

We should be able to start the plugin system if we have a database and still within the setup process.
fields.summary: Restarting Crowd during setup fails to startup plugin system

fields.description:
Allow Crowd to be used in a delegated environment where program managers take responsibility for their team members access to their repositories. Currently only a Crowd administrator can add users to groups which means that all user access allocation needs to be done by a central team to make sure that no one adds users to the super admin roles. 

Groups within crowd should be able to be managed by specified users (or groups) allowing those members to add/remove users from the group.

For example, we are looking at setting up the following group structure within Crowd for each;

project-admins
project-developers
project-users 

We should be able to define that members of the project-admins group can log into Crowd and add or remove users from the project-admins, project-developers and project-users group. They should only be able to manage this the groups that they have permissions for and not be able to see any of the Application, Users or Administration settings.

This way we can develop a properly de-centralised solution for our users.
fields.summary: Individual Group Administration Permissions

fields.description:
We need to upgrade existing directories' configurations with external ID attribute name.

We need to create a upgrade task to set default values (ones we know) into current LDAP configurations. This way, we will fetch external id of users and have the functionality working from day one. There is no risk of putting a wrong attribute name, because if attribute is not valid, it will be ignored.
fields.summary: Create an upgrade task to add the externalId attribute

fields.description: Currently it is too easy for an administrator to click through the crowd setup wizard and enable the openid & demo application and *not* set passwords for  either of the applications. It should not be possible to enable a default application without first changing the default password.
fields.summary: Force change of password when enabling the default applications in crowd

fields.description:
The DirectoryManager should throw a 

{{UserAlreadyExistsException}} if the user already exists ... instead it throws a {{InvalidUserException}}
fields.summary: DirectoryManager does not throw the correct exception if a user already exists.

fields.description: The Crowd console currently uses the REST client to change passwords. This should be done through the in-process Crowd API (ApplicationService).

fields.description:
Right now it is not possible to add a remote group in a Connector so that it becomes a member of a local group. Doing so will result in the following error:
{code}
2013-06-27 22:16:11,616 http-8260-6 ERROR [console.action.group.UpdateGroupMembers] Failed to add groups to group
com.atlassian.crowd.exception.ReadOnlyGroupException: Group <LDAPtest1> is read-only and cannot be updated
{code}
Where LDAPtest1 is the Remote group.

This is also highlighted here: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-3090

h3.Steps to Reproduce:
# Create a Connector directory, make sure that the *Manage Groups Locally* option is checked
# Create a local group into this Connector
# Sync the directory, and try to add a remote group that is synced into the locally created group in Step 2
fields.summary: Ability to add a Remote Group in a Connector to be a member of a Local Group

fields.description: Due to the fix for CWD-3307, it is not possible to use the REST API to do a case-sensitive user rename, e.g., from "Alice" to "alice". An alternative that does not involve doing a two-step rename should be available through the REST API.
fields.summary: Add a REST API to do case-sensitive user renames

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 8 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team
{panel}

Which means there is a small window of opportunity for a user rename to go undetected.

Steps to reproduce:
* Create a Read/Write LDAP directory
* Add a user to the directory from Crowd/JIRA/Confluence/Stash
* rename the user in the DLAP server
* kick a synch off in Crowd/JIRA/Confluence/Stash
* System will act as though the first user is deleted, and a new user is added.
fields.summary: When adding a user to a Read/Write LDAP directory, (Embedded) Crowd will not retrieve the UUID until next synchronisation

I have come across another NTLM solution from an Atlassian Expert, [NTLM for Confluence and Jira|http://turningright.co.nz/display/TurningRight/NTLM+Authenticator], which appears to be a fairly neat solution at a reasonable price so maybe we could update the documentation to point to this 3rd-party plugin instead of the deprecated one?

fields.description:
h1. Steps to reproduce

# Connect Crowd to an LDAP server that supports externalIds (CWD-3340).
# Create users X and B in the LDAP server
# Synchronise.
# In the LDAP server, delete user X and then rename user B to X.
# Synchronise.

h1. Expected outcome

The second synchronisation succeeds and the Crowd cache does not contain any user named B (the former B is now X).

h1. Actual result

(Unverified) Synchronisation fails. The Crowd cache still contains a user named B, and user X is still the former X.
fields.summary: LDAP synchronisation fails when user x is deleted and user b is renamed to x

fields.description:
h3. Description
This issue has been assigned CVE-2013-3925 by Mitre Corporation.
Previously reported issue CVE-2012-2926 (August 2012, CVSS score 6.4) was patched by introducing a new XFire servlet component into Crowd. The new component disables external entity resolution during XML parsing.
The new component has been configured to work for URLs with pattern /crowd/services/ but does not intercept calls to /crowd/services/2/ (etc). 

h3. Scope
An successful attack requires direct access to Crowd REST interface. As a result, only standalone Crowd servers are affected. 

A common configuration where an internal Crowd server is used by an Internet-facing Confluence, JIRA or other products is not vulnerable to an attack from the Internet.

h3. Fix
Please upgrade Crowd to 2.5.4 or 2.6.3. The issue has been resolved in these versions.

h3. Workaround
For older versions of Crowd there is a patched version of xfire-servlet.xml available attached to this ticket. It needs to replace the existing one inside a jar in your installation. See [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=376836952] for instructions for how to apply the patch.

If you use Web Application Firewalls, Apache ACLs or similar technology, you can filter access to {{/crowd/services}}.

h3. Patching Instructions moved up here from comment as comment is collapsed.
h3. Patch instructions
As well as the Fix Versions, this can be patched in older versions if you are unable to upgrade. The fix requires replacing the {{xfire-servlet.xml}} file in the {{crowd-server}} jar. 

h4. Patching
The corrected version of the file can be used with Crowd 2.3.7, 2.4.1 or any 2.5 or 2.6 release. See {{xfire-servlet.xml}} attached to this issue.

For example, for Crowd 2.4.2:
{noformat}
zip -u atlassian-crowd-2.4.2/crowd-webapp/WEB-INF/lib/crowd-server-2.4.2.jar xfire-servlet.xml
{noformat}

Or you can simply copy the attached [xfire-servlet.xml|https://jira.atlassian.com/secure/attachment/94422/xfire-servlet.xml] to {{crowd-webapp/WEB-INF/classes}}, followed by a Crowd restart.

h4. Older versions
With versions 2.1.2 or 2.2.9, unzip the file and manually edit it to remove all {{urlMap}} entries other than the first {{key="/*"}} entry:

{code:lang=none}
     <bean class="org.springframework.web.servlet.handler.SimpleUrlHandlerMapping">
         <property name="urlMap">
             <map>
                 <entry key="/*" value-ref="securityServerService"/>
-                <entry key="/1/*" value-ref="securityServerService"/>
-                <entry key="/2/*" value-ref="securityServerService2"/>
-                <entry key="/latest/*" value-ref="securityServerService2"/>
             </map>
         </property>
     </bean>
{code}

{panel}
*We have documented a security notice regarding this matter at - [Crowd Security Notice 2013-07-01|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Crowd+Security+Notice+2013-07-01]*
{panel}
fields.summary: Parsing of external XML entities can be exploited to retrieve files or make HTTP requests on the target network

fields.description:
The company I work for would like to implement CrowdID for our internal applications, but would like to see an improvement in the Crowd session handling to implement a maximum session duration, which would require users to re-enter their credentials after a set period of time regardless of whether their session remains active.
For example, with a session timeout of 1 hour, as long as you are active every 30 minutes, you can theoretically keep your single session open indefinitely. If there was a maximum session duration, you could require that every 24 hours a user's session is killed, and thus they need to re-authentication, thus plugging a potential security hole of abusing idle session timeout durations.

If we could rely on CrowdID requiring a fresh login every set period of time, we would be able to pass our internal security reviews more easily and move forward with implementation.

Originally discussed in CWDSUP-7882
fields.summary: Maximum session duration limitation

We need to have a consistent behaviour, so customers can get the benefits of CWD-995 when they connect the suite of Atlassian products to a Crowd server that is hooked to AD.
fields.summary: Synchronise user enable/disable status for Remote Crowd directories

fields.description: CWD-995 introduces synchronisation of AD active/inactive users. This feature may surprise sysadmins because it changes the behaviour of existing directories. Make it optional using a switch in the UI. It should be enabled by default for new directories, and disabled for existing directories. Therefore, customers can opt-in for this feature _only if_ they have read the documentation and understand the consequences.
fields.summary: Make active/inactive AD user sync an opt-in feature for existing directories

I have the follow groups in Crowd:
empregados
     comunicacao
     financeiro
     desenvolvimento
            desenvolvimento.diretoria
     site
             site.diretoria

I not assing users direct to group *empregados* (level 0), they are in the sub-groups, but I expected that all users are members of *empregados*.
Jira, Confluence and Stash show zero members in the group *empregados* even after sync user directories.   
The crowd console show nested users in group *empregados* correct.
The same problem with group *desenvolvimento* (level 1) the members of *desenvolvimento.diretoria* do not sync (level 2)
fields.summary: Members of nested groups are not syncronized in Jira, Confluence and Stash

fields.description:
I attempted to purchase an item from the [Atlassian store|https://swag.atlassian.com]. After clicking 'checkout', I was pushed to the [OpenID host|https://openid.atlassian.com] for authentication. I successfully logged in and was redirected back to the store host, which redirected me back to the OpenID host and the redirect loop continued until I stopped it after 5 minutes.

h5. Steps to reproduce

# (Optional) Create an OpenID profile on [https://openid.atlassian.com] using a {{+}} character in the email address.
# Visit the [Atlassian store|https://swag.atlassian.com]
## Add an item to your cart.
## Click 'checkout'.
# (Optional, if you did not create an OpenID profile above) Create an OpenID profile on [https://openid.atlassian.com] using a {{+}} character in the email address.
# Enter the redirect loop.
fields.summary: Email address with '+' character breaks OpenID flow

fields.description: Extract the unique user ID from the LDAP server, based on the known connection to LDAP server and attribute name. This allows detection of user updates relative to the static unique user ID, regardless of user name changes.
fields.summary: Retrieve external ID from LDAP

fields.description:
Currently, Crowd counts two same usernames residing in one application (but two different directories) as two users instead of one.

h4. Steps to Reproduce
# Create two different directories
# Create one user (with the same username) in each of these directories
# Add the directories into an application
# Count users against license by going to *Administration > Licensing* (click "Recalculate your user total")

h4. Expected Results
The two usernames should be counted as one, since they are the same usernames (and they're treated as the same user)

h4. Actual Results
The two usernames are treated differently and counted as two different users, instead of one.
fields.summary: Same usernames residing in one application & different directories should be counted as one user

fields.description:
Deactivating a directory does not remove users from the license count

h4. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a new directory and add it into a crowd Application
# Add some users
# Go to *Administration > Licensing* and click "Recalculate your user total"
# Deactivate the directory created in Step 1
# Recalculate the users again

h4. Expected Results
Users in the deactivated directory should not be counted against license

h4. Actual Results
Users in the deactivated directory are still counted against license

h4. Workaround
# Deactivate the users, or
# Remove the directory from all applications
fields.summary: Users residing in inactive directories are still counted against license

InvalidAuthenticationException:
{code}
public static InvalidAuthenticationException newInstanceWithName(final String name, final Throwable cause)
    {
        return new InvalidAuthenticationException("Account with name <" + name + "> failed to authenticate", cause);
    }
{code}

Having the cause is good, but crowds up the logs. It will be great if we can just throw the LDAP Error Code without the stack trace. Example:
{code}
Account with name <test> failed to authenticate: [LDAP: error code 49 - 80090308: LdapErr: DSID-0C090334, comment: AcceptSecurityContext error, data 52e, vece\u0000]
{code}
fields.summary: Long Stack Trace With Invalid LDAP Authentication Attempt (LDAP Error 49)

fields.description: Time to get everyone using the same directory configuration. This will also help Crowd know when they break things in the admin plugin! Or even need to add features as API's and features in Crowd change and evolve.
fields.summary: Embed the Embedded Crowd Directory Configuration plugin within Crowd

fields.description:
Here is the steps to reproduce the problem. 
# On the LDAP server, create an parent organization unit for users with the attribute " ou=spacetest" rather than "ou=spacetest", then create an user with a normal attribute "cn=space". 
# Create an parent organization unit for groups with the attribute "ou=groups" then create a group with a normal attribute "cn=confluence-users".
# add the "uniquemember" attribute in the group with the value: "cn=space, ou=spacetest,o=confluence,dc=momo,dc=com".
# Create a new ldap user directory user directory with the settings. 
# After synchronization, the user space is added in Confluence but without any membership setting with the group "confluence-users"
{noformat}
2013-05-31 14:38:27,099 DEBUG [scheduler_Worker-1] [directory.ldap.cache.AbstractCacheRefresher] synchroniseMemberships Updating memberships for 2 groups from Apache Directory Server 1.5.x Directory 2981889
2013-05-31 14:38:27,099 DEBUG [scheduler_Worker-1] [atlassian.crowd.directory.RFC4519Directory] getEntityNamesAsMap Performing USER search: baseDN =  ou=spacetest,o=jira,dc=momo,dc=com - filter = (objectclass=inetorgperson)
2013-05-31 14:38:27,104 DEBUG [scheduler_Worker-1] [atlassian.crowd.directory.RFC4519Directory] getEntityNamesAsMap Performing GROUP search: baseDN = ou=groups,o=jira,dc=momo,dc=com - filter = (objectclass=groupOfUniqueNames)
2013-05-31 14:38:27,116 DEBUG [scheduler_Worker-1] [atlassian.crowd.directory.RFC4519DirectoryMembershipsIterable] apply Unexpected DN in group 'jira-users': cn=admin,ou=users,o=jira,dc=momo,dc=com
.......
2013-05-31 14:38:27,117 DEBUG [scheduler_Worker-1] [atlassian.crowd.directory.RFC4519DirectoryMembershipsIterable] apply Unexpected DN in group 'jira-users': cn=testuser@test,ou=users,o=jira,dc=momo,dc=com
2013-05-31 14:38:27,117 DEBUG [scheduler_Worker-1] [atlassian.crowd.directory.RFC4519DirectoryMembershipsIterable] apply Unexpected DN in group 'jira-users': cn=space,ou=speacetest,o=jira,dc=momo,dc=com
........
2013-05-31 14:38:27,118 DEBUG [scheduler_Worker-1] [directory.ldap.cache.AbstractCacheRefresher] synchroniseMemberships found [ 0 ] remote user-group memberships, [ 0 ] remote group-group memberships in [ 8ms ]
{noformat}
 Regarding to the log file, it seems that the space had been trimmed in the "uniquemember" attribute value, as it has to be:
{code}
cn=space, ou=speacetest,o=jira,dc=momo,dc=com
{code} 
Instead of 
{code}
cn=space,ou=speacetest,o=jira,dc=momo,dc=com
{code}
fields.summary: Membership not synchronized for the user who got space in the attribute name

fields.description:
h1. Steps to reproduce

# Set up a Crowd instance with file-based directory configuration
# Request an event token
# Perform some change in an "immutable" directory to generates an event, such as creating a group.
# Request new events since the token was obtained

h1. Expected result

A GroupEvent is received.

h1. Actual outcome

No event is received.
fields.summary: Incremental sync does not work when using file-based directory configuration

fields.description: Have a function on Crowd to allow resetting the passwords for users in a particular directory or perhaps a particular group, or for all users at the same time.
fields.summary: Allow forcing a password reset for all users

fields.description:
When any application syncs with Crowd, it will capture *all* groups associated with the user. This is an expected behavior if these applications are mapped to the same directory in Crowd that contains the user. However, in the long run it would be confusing for administrators to manage multiple applications and see multiple irrelevant groups (such as confluence-users in Bamboo) shown in the user's profile.

*Suggestion:*
It would be great to allow selection of which groups to sync to an application despite connecting to the same directory.
fields.summary: Improvement for Crowd to have selectable group sync

fields.description:
This is a Embedded Crowd feature: new UI filed to define External Id
 - add text field for the unique user attribute
- pre-set the default depending on the type/implementation of the LDAP server
- upon upgrade to JIRA 6.1 the mapping should be checked
how to inform admins that the setting is incompatible with the LDAP server?
JIRA admin notification?
should we just inform or automatically change the setting?
fields.summary: Add LDAP Connection property for "External ID property name"

fields.description: We should support different DNs for the same user directory. This would allow get users/groups from different OUs without receiving the whole tree.
fields.summary: Support for multiple group/user DNs on LDAP user directory

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 8 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team
{panel}

fields.description:
The root of this issue is : Users are not notified in Jira/Confluence/Bamboo/Fisheye when their password has expired. CWD-3323

Now, we tried to workaround this by writing a Crowd plugin which would email users upon UserUpdatedEvents.

This works well when the attribute requiresPasswordChange is updated via the web console of Crowd; but it does not when the user tries to login in Jira and the attribute is updated in Crowd (the event is not generated)

So basically, events are not generated when a user is updated by Crowd itself to respect directory rules. Our plugin will never work and we will resort to writing a DB trigger (which is not really the best here but the only remaining option we have until the Crowd team does something)

Could you check the missing spots in Crowd where events should be generated ? Thx
fields.summary: Events are not generated when users are updated by directory rules

fields.description:
Hi Team.

I faced a behavior that I believe is not the ideal for our applications.
If user has Crowd authentication and the password is expired or the user is configured to change the password on next login then user only gets an "Incorrect Username or Password" message.
It was going to be awesome if the application that is using shows a message informing that to the user.

Thanks in advance.

Regards.
Celso Yoshioka,
Atlassian Support.
fields.summary: Advise users of integrated applications about expired passwords

fields.description:
Was originally raised against JIRA as JRA-26458

Incremental synch is based on the highestCommittedUSN attribute, and this is not cluster-safe AFAIK, so I imagine that this is one way it coud be broken, however at least one customer claims it happens for them even when attaching to a single node.

To make matters worse, incremental synch is on by default and is hidden in the advanced configuration.

fields.description:
In the admin console one can see a list of all groups from the LDAP Directory, but only "Groupname".
But there is no column with the "description" of the group.

This description is available from LDAP. It should be displayed in Confluence too, because often group names might not be speaking for themselves.

This will help the confluence administrator to assign rights.

Thanks and many greetings,
Henning

fields.description:
If an application has lowerCaseOutput set then it will never receive mixed-case names.

When user details posted to the '/user' resource are checked to make sure the payload entity matches the username in the database this is  currently a case-sensitive check, which fails because the returned lowercase output doesn't match the mixed case stored in Crowd.

For consistency with Crowd's case-insensitive, case-preserving behaviour this check should also be case-insensitive. The update shouldn't affect the existing case in the database.
fields.summary: Usernames in updates posted to /user should be checked case-insensitively

fields.description: The "View Group" page currently shows the sub-groups included in the current group. It would be very useful to also have the list of the groups that include the current group. That can be of great help when you have to manage complex hierarchies of nested groups.

fields.description:
h4. Background
As of Crowd 2.12.0, the application now provides an audit log to record:
* Changes to the system configuration of Crowd
* Adding or removing applications, updating application configuration
* Adding or removing directories, updating directory configuration

h4. Feature request summary 
This feature request is to optionally _extend_ the audit logging to include all *user/group/membership* changes as well (e.g. add/remove/disable). It would record who made those changes, whether by an admin (in which case the admin's username would be recorded) or as part of an automated process (such as an LDAP sync). If users or groups are removed from the system entirely, this log should document their removal as well as their final membership information prior to the removal from Crowd.

h4. Use cases
* Provides details audit trail to see which administrators made changes in user management
* Aids in recovery of users/groups accidentally removed from Crowd by retaining their membership information in the logs
fields.summary: Provide a detailed User/Group/Membership change log

fields.description: AUI 5 is a prerequisite for ADG-ifying Crowd (CWD-3195). However, as Crowd doesn't currently use much of the existing AUI it should be possible to upgrade and make AUI available for plugins before refreshing Crowd's UI.
fields.summary: Make AUI 5 available in Crowd

fields.description:
When using the User Import (CSV importer), if we set [Are your passwords encrypted = 'yes'] and import users with MD5 encrypted password, the password will be encrypted again when it gets imported to the external directory. 

I have tried this feature with Crowd v 2.5.2 and 2.6.2. The external directory in use is ApacheDS and I have set the directory configuration of Apache DS to use MD5.

h1. Repro steps
# Create an ldap connector (e.g. ApacheDS with MD5 password encoding for ease of testing)
# Import users from CSV, ticking the "passwords are already encrypted" radio box

h1. Observed
In LDAP directory, the saved value is MD5 hashed again

h1. Expected
It should be stored the same as it was in the CSV file
fields.summary: CSV Import re-encrypting the encrypted password

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 8 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team
{panel}

fields.description:
Crowd's caches are created by request, but there's a race condition: we check that they exist and then created them. Simultaneous attempts to create would see one of those attempts fail. We should use {{addCacheIfAbsent}} instead so EhCache takes care of the possible race.
The exception is caught and logged, so this shouldn't be causing problems, but fixing it will clear up noise in the logs.
fields.summary: Race condition in cache creation shows an error in the logs

fields.description:
For the fields of a group, each dutifully has a static {{Property}} listed in {{GroupTermKeys}} that we can use to plug a {{TermRestriction}} when searching. Each field except 'description'.

Looking at the source it appears that those static Properties are simply {{PropertyImpl}} s with a hard-coded string. Extrapolating, it would be nice if something like {{new PropertyImpl<String>("description", String.class)}} worked, but it doesn't.

My complaining is documented here:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/163548/is-there-any-way-to-search-a-group-s-description
fields.summary: Groups cannot be searched by their descriptions

fields.description:
The [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD025/Integrating+Crowd+with+Atlassian+JIRA+4.2+or+earlier] talks about {{com.atlassian.crowd.integration.seraph.v22.CrowdAuthenticator}} and {{com.atlassian.crowd.integration.seraph.JIRAAuthenticator}}, but these classes don't even exist in {{crowd-integration-client-2.5.3.jar}}.

Due to this reason it is not possible to integrate JIRA 4.1.x with Crowd 2.5.3's client libraries; instead, use the client libraries from Crowd 2.2.7, which remain compatible with later releases of the Crowd server.

Consider adding support providing an extension point so plugins can implement support.

fields.description:
The resource /group/membership is optimised for streaming XML responses, and does not currently produce JSON responses, unlike the other resources in Crowd's REST API.

Ideally, this resource should support JSON as well.
fields.summary: Support JSON responses in /group/membership

fields.description:
h4. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up a GET JSON call with no request body to REST API: {{http://<crowd-url>/crowd/rest/usermanagement/latest/group/membership}}
# Ensure that the response data type is in JSON

h4. Expected Results
The response should be in JSON, which contains full details of all group memberships, with users and nested groups.

h4. Actual Results
The response is in XML, whether or not we specify the response data type.

h4. Findings
When trying a GET JSON call to {{/user?username=<user>}}, it is able to return in either JSON or XML
fields.summary: REST API for "/group/membership" returns XML response when JSON response is requested

fields.description:
*Background of The Request*

For security purposes, Crowd currently does not have the option provided to the user to choose "Remember Me" in Crowd console. This feature is not included due to security issue. However, user should have the choice to decide whether to apply this feature into their Crowd's or not.

To add "Remember me" functionality to Crowd with the following criteria:
# Provide the option to enable/disable "Remember Me" function on Crowd administrators
# There needs to be a checkbox titled "Remember me" on the login screen of Crowd.
# Clicking checkbox should cause session to persist when web browser is quitted and restarted, unless session timeout occurs.
# Persistent session timeout should be configurable (default: 2 weeks)
# Functionality should be optional - checkbox should appear when configuration option is turned on
fields.summary: Provide "Remember me" option in Crowd login screen

fields.description:
When a user attempts to log in to jira or confluence with their alias it returns "invalid signin", but it still generates a SSO cookie with a crowd token. When I go in to the administration section of JIRA and Confluence and test crowd authentication, all of the users authenticate correctly. So, confluence and jira are able to authenticate the user but they don't seem to be able to recognize the SSO token generated for an aliased user.

Interestingly, if the user logs into crowd with their original username the generated SSO token is accepted by both confluence and jira. JIRA and confluence can't generate a valid SSO token for an aliased user, but CROWD can.

I would attach an error log but there isn't one. No errors are generated and nothing of any significance is in the log other than "xxxxmember failed to authenticate"

Any help with this would be appreciated.
fields.summary: Crowd alias fails with Confluence and JIRA SSO

fields.description:
A Stash customer had it connected to an AD instance with an extremely large amount of groups (in the order of 10s of thousands). The groups have been hidden by a filter, and the resulting synchronization process seems to have been running at a linear pace of (deleting) 100-120 groups/minute. This resulted in the sync lasting _days_.

Additionally, despite turning on INFO logging on Crowd classes did not result in any progress indication as CWD-3044 would suggest

I recommend investigating with minimum 10000 groups in the AD - whether the progress is similarly slow, or potentially other factors might have affected the customer's instance (e.g. low memory due to large amount of group data?), and whether the process can be optimized for this kind of edge cases (e.g. delete by queries rather than hibernate)
fields.summary: AD sync involving a large number of groups is slow

fields.description:
Since CWD-3188, incremental synchronisation with a remote Crowd will fall back to full synchronisation when inconsistencies cause failure. However, some cases don't cause failure. Specifically:

* Synchronisation changes for a locally-deleted user recreates that user.
* Membership changes to a nonexistent group are ignored.

These cases will only happen when the current local state is out of synch with the remote Crowd instance; they imply that there may be other problems. They should be detected so that Crowd falls back to full synchronisation.
fields.summary: Inconsistencies in Crowd incremental synchronisation don't cause failure

fields.description: CrowdDirectorySynchroniserImpl relies on locks to have mutual exclusion on the actual directory synchronisation. The locking mechanism can be very complex in clustered environments (e.g., clustered Confluence), Crowd should be defensive around it. In particular, logging should be improved to help diagnosing problems, and if possible, invariants should be asserted to fail early and minimise the risk of database corruption.
fields.summary: Improve logging and be defensive about posible locking failures when synchronising directories
